text: An acquaintance of mine heard something about some of the new variants being more virulent in kids, but I can't find any sources. It seems a bit implausible to me, but I wanted to try to track down where that idea came from before saying more about it

elements.text: An acquaintance of mine heard something about some of the new variants being more virulent in kids, but I can't find any sources. It seems a bit implausible to me, but I wanted to try to track down where that idea came from before saying more about it

text: Lol, "some"... The swipe typing on Android seems like it's deteriorating by the minute

elements.text: Lol, "some"... The swipe typing on Android seems like it's deteriorating by the minute

text: There was certainly some suggestion of this early on

elements.text: There was certainly some suggestion of this early on

attachments.title: Coronavirus: Impact of new variant on children investigated
attachments.text: Experts urgently assess whether the mutation of coronavirus spreads more easily among the young.
attachments.fallback: BBC News: Coronavirus: Impact of new variant on children investigated

text: And in the latest REACT study the youngest kids have the highest infection rates

elements.text: And in the latest REACT study the youngest kids have the highest infection rates

text: Although that's partly due to the fact that we have a pretty strict lockdown here in the UK, but primary schools are open for children of "key workers" (apparently around 20% of kids)

elements.text: Although that's partly due to the fact that we have a pretty strict lockdown here in the UK, but primary schools are open for children of "key workers" (apparently around 20% of kids)

text: <@U7JQGPGCQ> Interesting, thanks! Looks like that's referring to greater transmission (which *does* seem plausible), not virulence though. It's entirely possible that the two were conflated in the rumor I heard though

elements.text: Interesting, thanks! Looks like that's referring to greater transmission (which
seem plausible), not virulence though. It's entirely possible that the two were conflated in the rumor I heard though

text: I think (although can't now find anything to this effect) that early on it was thought that the higher number of cases in children could partly be due to more symptomatic infections meaning fewer undetected cases. I haven't seen anything to suggest there's actually noticeably higher risk for kids in terms of hospitalizations, long covid, deaths, or this child specific immune reaction (Kawasaki disease?) though, if that's what the rumour was

elements.text: I think (although can't now find anything to this effect) that early on it was thought that the higher number of cases in children could partly be due to more symptomatic infections meaning fewer undetected cases. I haven't seen anything to suggest there's actually noticeably higher risk for kids in terms of hospitalizations, long covid, deaths, or this child specific immune reaction (Kawasaki disease?) though, if that's what the rumour was

text: :thumbsup: That's helpful, thanks. Could also just be that higher transmission means more of the very rare events, so more kids getting sick even if the rate / infection remains constant

elements.text: That's helpful, thanks. Could also just be that higher transmission means more of the very rare events, so more kids getting sick even if the rate / infection remains constant
